subject: Productivity
title: The Four-Day Work Week
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Four-Day Work Week usable.

hook.text: Companies across the world are testing a radical idea: work four days, get paid for five.

buildup.text: Trials in Iceland, the UK, and Japan showed productivity held steady or improved with shorter weeks.

discovery.text: Workers reported better health, lower stress, and higher engagement with one fewer day.

twist.text: Not all industries fit. Hospitals, retail, and service jobs face scheduling challenges the trials didn't solve.

climax.text: The four-day week challenges a century-old assumption: that more hours always mean more output.

punchline.text: The five-day week isn't a law of nature. It's a choice.

quiz.question: What did four-day work week trials generally show?
